snippet: A $5 million check from Sheldon Adelson underscores how last year’s landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance has made it possible for a wealthy individual to influence an election.
abstract: Contribution of $5 million from billionaire casino owner Sheldon Adelson to a super PAC supporting Republican presidential hopeful Newt Gingrich comes just in time to bolster Gingrich's campaign for the South Carolina primary; last-minute injection underscores how 2011 landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance has made it possible for a wealthy individual to influence an election, as Adelson’s contribution is 1,000 times the $5,000 he could legally give in 2012.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and ERIC LIPTON
byline.contributor: Nicholas Confessore reported from Manchester, and Eric Lipton from Washington. Trip Gabriel and Jeremy W. Peters contributed reporting from Manchester, and Jeff Zeleny from Bedford, N.H.

lead_paragraph: A $5 million check from Sheldon Adelson underscores how last year’s landmark Supreme Court ruling on campaign finance has made it possible for a wealthy individual to influence an election.

headline.seo: Sheldon Adelson, a Billionaire, Gives Gingrich a Big Lift
headline.main: A Big Check, and Gingrich Gets a Big Lift
headline.print_headline: For Gingrich, A Rich Friend And a Big Lift
